comments.text:
I was born in 1979, I actually remember cameras that you had to MANUALLY 
wind the film once it was placed inside, and had to MANUALLY insert a flash 
stick, and MANUALLY adjust the lens... and yes, paying for the film and the 
photos to be developed did make us a lot more selective about what we took 
photos of.

I appreciate the digital formats today, but I definitely prefer to hold a 
photograph in my hand, too. Just like I prefer to hold a book in my hand, 
and not read it on a computer screen. Nothing wrong with the technological 
advancements, but folks will always prefer the technology that they grew up 
with. And yes, you're still a kid. My own daughter was born in 1998. =)

I do believe that some of them would not have any physical photographs, 
though. Many households have completely switched over to digital.. *shrugs*

comments.author: Tecnovlog

comments.text:
+Tecnovlog In my house, we also have pictures from the 20th and 
19th centuries.  Digital reprints, mostly; many of the originals are gone.  
Destroyed.  By time.  Definitively.  Never ever to be seen again in their 
original form.

Every year, they all fade.  No potential.  A *guaranteed* fate.

Also, something else we have: digital backups of important computer data 
from the 90's; not very much stuff, granted (a few pictures and text 
documents), but it's still there, alive and kicking on our hard drives.

I even have copies of my own personal computer files from the early 2000s, 
and I was a pretty irresponsible and ignorant computer user back then.

Silly estimations like "XX% of your stuff will be gone in X amount of 
years" are BS, not only because you're misrepresenting discarded 
information as being lost information, but because trying to estimate how 
much data I will lose when you don't actually know my computer habits.

I personally understand and accept the risks of technology because I 
understand and accept the risks of physical media like photographs.  I've 
weighed them against one another, and I choose and support digital media 
because it is not only potentially eternal, but WAY more convenient than 
physical media.

But, also, like I said before: people should learn the lessons that 
physical media has to teach, too.  It helps people become more responsible 
consumers and producers of media, physical AND digital.

I am done, though.  This is tiresome, because I'm just repeating myself 
now.  I won't forget to mute the thread this time.

Good luck with your photoprints.

comments.author: Tecnovlog

comments.text:
+Tecnovlog  Just to clarify: I have *never* said that burning DVDs was how 
one *should* archive digital information.

I've said  backup discs (HDDs) paired with automatically updating and 
re-archiving cloud-based storage are what people should use to protect 
their information.  That was the point of most of what I've said: physical 
pictures and film will ALWAYS fade, no matter what, but digital 
information, as long as it's backed up and updated once every so often, is 
as eternal as it's keeper/s.

Also, yes, estimated.  However, they're estimations based on quantified 
numbers that formed a definite grouping pattern.

And, yes, there are plenty of ways to store bit-based information for - 
hypothetically - thousands of years, but you can already print data on 
paper with QR codes.  With a modified QR reader designed to handle 16 or 32 
bit blocks, you could print or inscribe as much information as you wanted 
to on any physical object.  Printed bits and bytes are nothing new.

Plus, the method to manually decode QR codes is also EXTREMELY well 
documented, which means that QR codes now will be decipherable for as long 
as they and at least one codex or cryptographer physically survive.

+DaShonuff Did you know that certain nomadic tribes in Asia believed that 
photographs stole a part of your soul and made you less human?

True story.

Another true story: this isn't a tale about the Human Condition.  I'm not 
even being unfair.

Children aren't less human because they don't get to "hold a physical 
picture" or waste money on extra film or whatever.

I lived most of my life being forced to use film cameras because my 
family couldn't afford to buy even the lowest-end digital cameras.

Then I got a cameraphone naught but 6 years ago at 17, and it didn't change 
a thing, other than the fact that I KEPT more pictures that I took, because 
I could retake them.

I'm not better off because I had to be extra careful when taking shots or 
worry about leaving my film somewhere too hot, or worry about the idiot 
running the 1-hour-photo doesn't ruin my roll of film (that's happened to 
me, by the way).

You know what I think when I hold an old picture?  "Should I be handling 
this without gloves?"  =L

Kids should be taught to appreciate the origins of technology, and should 
be introduced to tactile machinery at young ages so they can develop 
tactile problem-solving skills rather than just logical skills through the 
use of GUI, but they're not "less-human" if they don't.

**I'm done discussing this, by the way.  I'll read your response, but I'm 
going to mute this thread after today.

comments.text:
+FlipFlopGaming The MPAA is archaic.

I had to look up the proper name, but ALL acetate film suffers from Vinegar 
Syndrome, even in hyper-controlled environments.

Even in the microclimate environments of the ex-wine-cellar vaults in 
wherever (Italy? I think), the MPAA's "physical" copies of film will last 
only ~200 years before they begin to degrade irreversibly, and that's 
assuming the MPAA can keep those physical copies in that microclimate for 
that long.

If you want to preserve permanent media quality, you HAVE to convert your 
media to something that can be copied infinitely and without error, so that 
you can have an unlimited amount of backup files stored in an unlimited 
amount of places.

This is the philosophy of people who like storing files on torrents (not 
just illegally distributed movies; people like The GIMP Foundation, or 
other GNU publishers; lots of people have a copy, so if one distributor 
goes dead, there will be hundreds more to pick up the slack).

Also: we'll always have the technology to read old data unless the world 
goes completely tits up.

Plus, you don't even have to worry about it all that often.  Data is so 
easily converted to new formats, it's silly.  For example: when you upload 
a YouTube video, YouTube re-encodes the video several times in several 
different formats within a matter of seconds, even for files several 
gigabytes in size.

This isn't a problematic question, either.  You may subjectively like the 
idea of film slides more, and you're completely free to choose to store 
film in film slides instead of digital scans of film slides, but 
*objectively* it is 100% quantifiably better for longevity of image 
quality to keep image scans of your film slides and just transfer them onto 
a new backup disc and re-save them in the newest .jpg or .png or whatever 
image standards every few years.
comments.author: Glasses^2

comments.text:
The MPAA (Motion Picture Association of America) backs up all new movies on 
Film. According to them, Film is the only way to truly preserve the images. 
Why?
Because a DVD would last forever, but the devices needed to view a DVD 
won't. Media changes fairly quickly, and unless you want to constantly copy 
and paste all of your media into a new format then the best way to totally 
preserve an image is through an analog solution. After all, I only need 
light to see my old images. I don't need a computer.

you'll get over such trivial sadness as you get older though. As a kid/teen 
everything seems like the end of the world or sad,but you get perspective 
in hindsight. I was no different. I'm 25 now. Think how 80year olds 
feel,they had record players and no TV sets even as kids in the 30s and 
40s. 50year olds had arcade machines in the 70s when they were entering 
their teens only,also 70s console games and Sony walkman became a thing 
only in the 80s. 40year olds remember laser discs(not CD) for music/films 
in the 80s,and betamax/VHS tapes as well as the game consoles and computer 
games in the early/mid 80s. 30year olds remember when the internet 
came,when laptops came. CDs came in early 90s. I got my cassette player for 
my 10th birthday,a CD player in 2004,an MP4player in 2008. Kids don't know 
such devices. I remember when nobody had cell phones,when there were no lcd 
monitors or Tvs. I used a bloody rotary phone! And yet, at 25,you realize 
it's not that important if kids remember this or not,some kids will learn 
history of it on their own,and as adults people learn anyway of it.My mom 
had her own processing of photos in a dark room,also a slide machine for 
slides(!),black and white photos actually too till the early 90s. I recall 
going to rent a VHS often as a kid,they had those here into the mid00s at 
least,and VHS dominated till early 00s,despite DVD coming in 1995. They'll 
go through the same in 10-15 years,so no worries,haha.

comments.text:
The FE2 and FM2 are newer, less accumulated wear on average. 

Higher maximum shutter speed - 1/4000 sec. rather than 1/1000 sec. Lower 
minimum shutter speed - 8 sec. rather than 1 sec. Higher flash sync speed - 
1/250 sec. rather than 1/125 sec.

The F3 should be more durable as it was a professional model.
comments.author: Michael Scheele

comments.text: +Michael Scheele What's the difference?
comments.author: Jacob Avner

comments.text:
Thanks for the recommendation. I already have the 50mm and a 60-200 Sigma 
lens. My dad had a Nikon something or other when he was a teenager.
comments.author: Jacob Avner

comments.text:
In that price range, I'd suggest a Nikon FE or FM. Both are semi-pro models 
and fairly durable. The difference is the FE has auto-exposure (aperture 
priority) while the FM is strictly manual exposure. Also get a Nikkor (or 
Nikon Series E) 50mm f/1.8. If you can't find an online seller that is 
reputable, try checking the surviving camera stores in your area.

It takes more discipline as you don't get immediate confirmation of 
composition and focus plus you only have 12-36 exposures per roll of 35mm 
film.

That would be an instant/Polaroid camera. Cool bit of info for all the kids 
here: The Polaroid concept inspired the concept and name of Instagram, as a 
Polaroid camera was the first type of INSTAnt camera, which allowed you to 
share images just after they had been taken. The icon is reminiscent of the 
device.

It's also awesome that Fuji and some smaller manufacturers are rebooting 
the physical instant camera devices. (Search: Fuji Instax)

By the way, Alize: hold on to that instant camera; they are still worth 
quite some money today, especially if it's an original Polaroid.

top_comment.text:
Having digital cameras and digital storage is awesome. I don't care what 
anyone says, it's FAR more reliable than physical photographs and film 
negatives. Digital data is VERY hard to destroy. Your computer or 
hard-drive screw up? Then pay someone to retrieve the data. In the case of 
physical photographs, if those get destroyed via flood, fire, etc then they 
are gone. Data can be retrieved from hard-drives even in some of the most 
serious fires. All that being said. The digital camera age, has given 
virtually everyone in the world the notion that they are a photographer. If 
you can't take an old manual SLR or even an automatic film camera like the 
ones they used in this video, and take a picture and KNOW that the quality 
and composition will turn out well, then you are NO photographer!!!﻿
top_comment.author: HBKCommish

 I suspect very few people are ready to shell out up to $10,000 in hopes of 
getting a selfie or Facebook "what I had for lunch" pic from a dead HD or 
other device.. And if you check on using such recovery service, you'll see 
there's no guarantee of getting anything.
Backup, no matter the medium used, is important. Have at least a second 
copy elsewhere. But if someone is seriously into picture-taking, they 
should be knowledgeable on using film photography. It's a great artform.

comments.text:
+therealcrazycallum
children don't need to know about any of this. they can,but don't need to. 
It won't benefit humanity in any way for kids to know this kind of stuff( 
them having empathy for all, no matter their 
orientation/religion/race/nation etc however is something humantiy will 
benefit from ). Once they become teens and adults,they will naturally find 
everything out(we all did,even if we didn't know or care to know as 
kids).If you're 14,then you know how kids are,often they can also lack 
empathy,because they don't realize how their actions/words can hurt 
others,all the nuances. And many kids can be short-sighted,not a broad 
worldview at all. So it comes with the territory. I'm 25,but I used a tv 
without a remote and a rotary phone,VHS etc,but had I always used a 
remote,cellphone and DVD/Netflix I wouldn't have known about the prior tech 
until I grew up. Kids tend to want instant gratification,as we all,but they 
have no patience usually,as they mature their perceptions will shift.So it 
is NOT this generation,it is every generation,it's childhood !! And 10 
years from now you will be very different from how you are now as well.
